- `todos` collector: 45 minutes

During these long runs, there is no visible output to stderr or stdout until the collector completes.

```
lotteryrisk: blamed 500/8854 files (5.6%)
lotteryrisk: blamed 1000/8854 files (11.3%)
todos: scanned 1000/8854 files (11.3%)
```

title: bd import -i - should support stdin convention
description:
Running `stringer scan . | bd import -i -` fails with:

```
Error opening input file: open -: no such file or directory
```

The `-i -` convention for reading from stdin is a well-established Unix pattern used by tools like `cat`, `curl`, `tar`, `docker`, etc. Users naturally reach for `-i -` since the `-i` flag exists.

**Current workaround:** `bd import` does read from stdin by default when `-i` is not specified, so `stringer scan . | bd import` works. However, the `-i -` form is so common in Unix tooling that users will try it first, especially since the stringer README likely documents a `stringer scan | bd import -i -` pipeline.

**Proposed fix:** Treat `-` as a special value for the `-i` flag, meaning "read from stdin." This is a trivial change (check if the filename is `"-"` and use `os.Stdin` instead of `os.Open`).

**Note:** This is technically a beads issue rather than a stringer issue, but is filed here since it was discovered during stringer evaluation and affects the recommended stringer-to-beads pipeline.

title: Test file detection heuristics need project-structure awareness
description:
The patterns collector uses naming heuristics (`test_*.py`) to detect whether source files have corresponding tests, but it does not account for separate test directory structures that are common in large projects.

**Problem:** In Home Assistant Core (8,854 source files, 6,934 test files), stringer flagged 8,878 files as "missing tests" because the tests live in `tests/components/<name>/` rather than alongside the source files in `homeassistant/components/<name>/`. This caused a massive false-positive flood: 86.5% of all signals were false missing-test alerts, drowning out real signals.

**Proposed solution:** Support one or more of:
- Configurable test directory mapping in `.stringer.yaml` (e.g., `test_roots: [{src: "homeassistant/", tests: "tests/"}]`)
- Auto-detection of common project structures where `tests/` mirrors `src/` or the main package directory
- Heuristic: if a `tests/` directory exists at the repo root and mirrors the source tree structure, use that mapping automatically

This is important for stringer to be useful on large, well-tested projects that happen to use a separate test directory layout.

title: C3: Patterns Collector
description: Detects code patterns indicating tech debt: large files, missing test coverage, deep nesting, and potential dead code. Uses language-agnostic heuristics.

title: C3.1: Detect large files
description: Flag files exceeding configurable line threshold (default 500 from config). Count lines efficiently (bufio.Scanner). Include file path, line count, and threshold in signal.

title: C3.2: Detect missing test coverage via heuristics
description: Use naming heuristics to identify test files: *_test.go, *.test.js, *.test.ts, test_*.py, *_spec.rb, etc. For each source file, check if a corresponding test file exists. Flag source files with no apparent test.

title: C3.3: Calculate test-to-source ratio
description: Calculate test-to-source ratio per module/directory. Ratio = test file count / source file count. Flag directories below configurable threshold (default 0.1). Include ratio and file counts in signal.

title: C3.4: Detect deeply nested directory structures
description: Flag directories that are nested more than a configurable depth (default 6 levels). Deep nesting often indicates over-engineering or poor organization. Include full path and depth in signal.

title: C3.5: Detect potential dead code indicators
description: Detect: commented-out code blocks (consecutive commented lines > threshold), unused exports (language-agnostic heuristic: exported symbols not referenced elsewhere). Use grep-based heuristics, not AST parsing.

title: C3.6: Configurable thresholds
description: Read all thresholds from .stringer.yaml: max_file_lines, min_test_ratio, max_nesting_depth, dead_code_threshold. Provide sensible defaults. Override via CLI flags where applicable.

title: C7.2: Emit vulnerability signals with severity

title: C7.3: Graceful degradation when govulncheck unavailable

Document the optional dependency in stringer docs. Consider bundling a minimal vuln DB client that doesn't require the govulncheck binary.

Apply ignore-path filtering and confidence scoring. USER RESEARCH NOTE: Confidence scoring heuristics must be documented and explainable to users (see UX1.5 stringer-4qs.5). Age of TODO via git blame, author activity, and proximity to recent changes are candidate signals. Users will filter on --min-confidence without understanding what it means — the heuristics need to be transparent, not a black box.

Use regex to match common formats: // TODO: ..., /* FIXME ... */, # TODO ..., etc. Walk directory tree, respect .gitignore. Return slice of RawSignal with Source='todos', Kind set to the matched keyword (lowercased), FilePath, Line, and Title extracted from the comment text.

title: Empty created_at timestamps break beads import
description:
The patterns collector (and potentially others) emits `"created_at": ""` in JSONL output. Beads import rejects these with:

```
parsing time "" as "2006-01-02T15:04:05Z07:00": cannot parse "" as "2006"
```

This affects ~97% of signals. For example, all 10,261 pattern signals in a Home Assistant Core scan had empty timestamps and were rejected on import.

**Expected behavior:** Should either omit the `created_at` field entirely, use the current timestamp as a fallback, or use a sentinel value that beads accepts.

**Reproduction:** Run `stringer scan` on any repository and pipe to `bd import`. Observe that most signals fail to import due to empty timestamp fields.
close_reason: Fixed in fix/scan-bugs branch: added omitempty to CreatedAt JSON struct tag

title: Duplicate stringer-generated label in signal output
description:
Every signal emitted by stringer has `"stringer-generated"` listed twice in the labels array.

**Example:**
```json
"labels": ["missing-tests", "stringer-generated", "stringer-generated", "patterns"]
```

**Expected:** Labels should be deduplicated before emitting:
```json
"labels": ["missing-tests", "stringer-generated", "patterns"]
```

This likely occurs because the `stringer-generated` label is added both by the individual collector and by the common signal emission code path.
